title: First bedrest samples arrive at exploration biobank in Portugal
summary: From the ESA Blogs.
detailed_news: ESA's new Exploration Biobank received its first biological samples linked to European space research in Portugal this week. The shipment contained over 1400 human samples from the Vivaldi III bedrest and dry-immersion campaign. The biological repository will remain stored at –80°C in remotely monitored freezers.

title: ESA Awards Contract for Reusable Rocket Stage Recovery Vessel
summary:
The European Space Agency (ESA) has awarded a contract for the design of a reusable rocket stage recovery vessel to the Italian aerospace and defence systems company Ingegneria Dei Sistemi (IDS). The project is part of a broader contract awarded to the Italian rocket builder Avio for the development of a reusable rocket upper stage. […]
The post ESA Awards Contract for Reusable Rocket Stage Recovery Vessel appeared first on European Spaceflight.
detailed_news: Ingegneria Dei Sistemi (IDS) has been awarded a contract for the design of a reusable rocket stage recovery vessel. The project is part of a broader contract awarded to the Italian rocket builder Avio. In late September, ESA awarded a €40 million contract to Avio for the development of a reused rocket upper stage.

title: Once unthinkable, NASA and Lockheed now consider launching Orion on other rockets
summary: "We're trying to crawl, then walk, then run into our reuse strategy."
detailed_news: Orion spacecraft and Space Launch System rocket have been attached at the hip for the better part of two decades. Lockheed Martin has begun to pivot toward a future in which the Orion spacecraft fits into commercial space applications. In interviews, company officials said that if NASA wanted to buy Orion missions as a "service," rather than owning and operating the spacecraft. NASA and Lockheed are working on a plan to reuse components of the Orion spacecraft. The plan calls for a step-by-step approach. Lockheed will never achieve "full and rapid reusability" for Orion like SpaceX is attempting with its Starship vehicle. But Orion is here and ready for its first astronauts in 2026. Ars is a trusted source in a sea of information. You don’t need to know everything, only what’s important. With our unique combination of technical savvy and wide-ranging interest in the technological arts and sciences, we can help you understand the world around you.

title: Isaacman Back in the Running for NASA Administrator
summary: Jared Isaacman is among a group of candidates being interviewed by NASA Acting Administrator Sean Duffy to take the top job at the agency on a permanent basis.  President Trump […]
detailed_news: Jared Isaacman is among a group of candidates being interviewed by NASA Acting Administrator Sean Duffy to take the top job at the agency on a permanent basis. President Trump nominated Isaacman for the position on January 20, but withdrew it at the end of May in a move widely attributed to Trump’s falling out with Elon Musk. NASA confirmed to SpacePolicyOnline.com that Sean Duffy met with Isaacman last week and also is interviewing other candidates. Isaacman, who’s nickname is Rook, has remained above the fray posting on X (@rookisaacman) about his gratitude to the President for nominating him in the first place.

title: Starship Block 2 and Pad 1 end on a high note with Flight 11
summary:
SpaceX completed the use of Block 2 and Pad 1 on a high note with…
The post Starship Block 2 and Pad 1 end on a high note with Flight 11 appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: SpaceX completed the use of Block 2 and Pad 1 on a high note with a completely successful mission with Flight 11. All 33 engines were running at liftoff, and unlike Flight 10, no engines shut off during the ascent. With the boost back complete, and for the final time, Booster 15-2 separated its hotstage ring to let it fall into the gulf. Super Heavy Booster 15-2 was down-selected from 13 engines to five engines, then down to three. This landing burn profile will enable more redundancy during the final adjustment phase of the landing burn, and allowing the booster to exert greater control over its trajectory. The booster entered a hover above the Gulf before shutting off all its engines, dropping into the water, and exploding. The day after launch, SpaceX released drone footage of the belly flop and landing. Flight 11 was a perfect send-off for Blocks 1 and 2 and for Pad 1 as SpaceX ends flight tests this year on a high note. Next up is Block 3, Raptor 3, and Pad 2(B) with Booster 18 and Ship 39. It is unclear when these vehicles will be ready for single-vehicle testing and eventually full-stack testing.

title: Live coverage: Overnight launch planned for 28 more Starlink satellites
summary: The Starlink 10-52 mission is anticipated to be SpaceX’s 130th Falcon 9 launch of the year. The rocket’s liftoff from pad 40 at Cape Canaveral Space Force Station is scheduled for Thursday, Oct. 16, at 5:27 a.m. EDT (0927 UTC).
detailed_news: SpaceX launched the Starlink 10-52 mission from Space Launch Complex 40 at 5:27 a.m. EDT (0927 UTC) The company used its drone ship, ‘Just Read the Instructions,’ to recover the booster nearly 8.5 minutes after liftoff. This was the 138th landing on this vessel and the 519th booster landing to date.

CIRA was contracted by Space Rider Re-entry Module prime contractor, Thales Alenia Space, in late 2021 to oversee a series of drop tests.

title: Beyond the downlink: Why Earth-independent AI is the next moat in space operations
summary:
Every new space mission runs into the same wall: physics and fragility. Physics, because the speed of light and contested spectrum make real-time decision-making from the ground impossible when you need it most. Fragility, because modern space systems are software-defined, interconnected, and therefore exposed to radiation-induced faults, cascading anomalies and increasingly sophisticated cyber threats. The […]

title: Flying through the biggest solar storm ever recorded
summary: No communication or navigation, faulty electronics and collision risk. At ESA’s mission control in Darmstadt, teams faced a scenario unlike any before: a solar storm of extreme magnitude. Fortunately, this nightmare unfolded not in reality, but as part of the simulation campaign for Sentinel-1D, pushing the boundaries of spacecraft operations and space weather preparedness.
detailed_news: ESA simulation campaign for Sentinel-1D, scheduled for launch on 4 November 2025. The exercise replicated the effects of a catastrophic solar storm on satellite operations to test the team’s ability to respond without satellite navigation and under severe electronic disruption. The simulation team has modelled a massive, X45-class flare, with intense X-ray and ultraviolet radiation disrupting radar systems, communications, and tracking data. An event of such magnitude would severely degrade the quality of conjunction data. Single-event upsets became even more frequent, impairing systems and shortening operational life. GNSS signals degraded further, star trackers went blind and battery charging events added to the chaos. The simulation will provide critical insights for the constitution of European-wide space weather operational services.

title: ESA Exploration Biobank in Portugal Receives First Human Samples
summary:
The European Space Agency’s (ESA) Exploration Biobank in Lisbon, Portugal, has received an initial batch of 1,422 samples, which will be used to validate the facility’s workflow. In July, ESA awarded a €300,000, 24-month contract to Portugal’s Gulbenkian Institute of Molecular Medicine (GIMM) to establish the agency’s Exploration Biobank. The contract was part of an […]
The post ESA Exploration Biobank in Portugal Receives First Human Samples appeared first on European Spaceflight.
detailed_news: The European Space Agency’s (ESA) Exploration Biobank in Lisbon, Portugal, has received an initial batch of 1,422 samples. The facility will store human samples from space missions and studies investigating the effects of microgravity on the human body. Once the facility is certified, what remains of the 4,380 human samples collected as part of the Vivaldi III study that have not yet been delivered will be transferred.

title: ESA Open Day 2025: an unforgettable journey through space science at ESAC
summary: English ESA Open Day 2025: An Unforgettable Journey Through Space Science at ESAC
detailed_news: The European Space Agency opened the doors of ESAC near Madrid for an inspiring day of discovery. Visitors had the opportunity to explore ESA’s window to the Universe, where missions studying our Solar System, the Milky Way and the distant Universe are operated and analysed. More than two thousand participants of all ages enjoyed an unforgettable day filled with curiosity, innovation, and a shared passion for exploring the Universe.

title: Live coverage: SpaceX to launch 2nd batch of satellites for Space Development Agency constellation
summary: The mission, dubbed Tranche 1 Transporter Layer C, will add another 21 satellites into the burgeoning constellation for the Space Development Agency. Liftoff from pad 4E at Vandenberg Space Force Base is scheduled for 4:12 p.m. PDT (7:12 p.m. EDT / 2312 UTC).
detailed_news: The Space Development Agency is set to add another 21 satellites to its burgeoning low Earth orbit constellation thanks to a launch onboard a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket. SpaceX aims to launch the T1TL-C mission from Space Launch Complex 4 East at Vandenberg Space Force Base no earlier than Wednesday, Oct. 15, at 4:03 p.m. PDT. The rocket will fly on a southerly trajectory upon departure from the California coastline. A Falcon 9 was able to launch from Vandenberg Space Force Base at 12:43 a.m. PDT (0743 UTC) SpaceX launched 60 more Starlink internet relay platforms into orbit Sunday. The company touts a streak of nearly 300 satellites launched since June without a spacecraft failure.

title: Launch Roundup: Falcon 9 to launch six missions in one week
summary:
Following the successful flight of Starship Flight 11 on Monday, SpaceX is set to continue…
The post Launch Roundup: Falcon 9 to launch six missions in one week appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: Starship Flight 11 launched from Starbase, Texas on Monday, Oct. 13, at 7:23 PM EDT (23:23 UTC) Ship 38 was lifted into space by Super Heavy Booster 15, which made its second flight to space on Flight 11. SpaceX is set to continue its impressive launch cadence with six Falcon 9 missions in one week. China now has four launches planned for the week, and Rocket Lab successfully launched an Electron from New Zealand on Tuesday. Falcon 9 launched a new batch of internet satellites on Monday for Amazon’s Project Kuiper constellation. The KF-03 mission launched on Oct. 13 at 9:58 PM EDT (Tuesday, 01:58 UTC), with 24 communication satellites flying on a northeast trajectory into low-Earth orbit. This mission had suffered considerable delays due to the unsuitable weather conditions in Florida last week. Falcon 9 is set to launch the Starship Group 10-52 mission on Thursday, Oct. 16, at 2:42 AM EDT (06:42 UTC) from SLC-40 at the CCSFS in Florida. Falcon 9 will carry 21 satellites on a due south trajectory toward a polar orbit. Supporting this flight is booster B1093, which will be flying for the seventh time. The booster will land atop SpaceX’s west coast droneship Of Course I Still Love You. The final Falcon 9 launch of the week is scheduled for Monday, Oct. 20, at 7:00 AM PDT (14:00 UTC) from SLC-4E in California. Booster B1075 will deliver a further 28 v2 Mini Starlink satellites into the constellation’s Group 11 shell for the Starlink Group 11-5 mission. The booster first flew on June 3, 2021.

title: Rocket Lab launches 7th StriX Earth observation satellites for Japan-based Synspective
summary: The ‘Owl New World’ mission was the 13th orbital Electron launch of 2025. The synthetic aperture radar satellite was deployed into a circular low Earth orbit roughly 50 minutes after liftoff from Mahia, New Zealand.
detailed_news: Japan-based Earth observation company, Synspective, launched its seventh StriX satellite into low Earth orbit. Rocket Lab Electron rocket took flight from Pad A at Launch Complex 1 to begin a roughly 50-minute-long mission. The mission, dubbed ‘Owl New World’, continued the avian theming to Synspective’s missions with Rocket Lab. Liftoff of the ‘IoT 4 You and Me’ mission happened at 9:43 a.m. NZDT on Feb. 9. The mission was the company’s 59th Electron rocket launch to date. Rocket Lab broke ground on a new launch pad on Virginia's Eastern Shore last week.

summary:
Impulse Space, the innovative startup founded by SpaceX veteran Tom Mueller, has unveiled plans for…
The post Impulse Space sets sights on the Moon with new Lunar Lander in development appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: Impulse Space has unveiled plans for a new lunar lander. It is designed to deliver up to three tonnes of payload to the Moon’s surface. The announcement highlights the company's ambition to fill a ‘critical gap’ in lunar cargo capabilities, positioning it as a key player in the growing commercial space race. Impulse Space has unveiled plans for a lunar lander. The company is targeting 2028 for the lander's first missions. The lander will use Helios, which handles the journey from low Earth orbit through trans-lunar injection to lunar orbit. Helios is compatible with multiple launch vehicles, broadening its accessibility.

title: Gravity assists: trading energy with the planets
summary: Is there life on Terran V? Join the adventure to the fictional planet and find out what it takes to reach the farthest frontiers of deep space.
detailed_news: The gravity assist is one of the most important techniques in deep-space navigation. By carefully passing close to a planet, a spacecraft can exchange orbital momentum with the much larger body. From the spacecraft’s perspective, this results in a change in trajectory and a significant boost (or reduction) in speed.

title: SpaceX launches final Version 2 Starship-Super Heavy rocket
summary: This was the fifth and final flight of this iteration of the rocket, which has been marred by a number of setbacks. The first Starship Version 3 is expected to debut in 2026.
detailed_news: SpaceX launched its Version 2 Starship-Super Heavy rocket on Monday. The rocket made it through the point of peak heating as well as the greatest point of atmospheric pressure with the vehicle mostly in tact. The only notable hiccup during ascent was that one of the planned 13 Raptor engines on the Super Heavy booster, tail number B15, didn’t reignite during the boostback burn.

title: Another Successful Starship Test Flight as SpaceX Readies a New Version
summary: SpaceX achieved a second successful Starship test flight in a row this evening. Integrated Flight Test-11 or IFT-11 lifted off from Starbase, Texas and splashed down in the Indian Ocean […]
detailed_news: SpaceX achieved a second successful Starship test flight in a row this evening. Integrated Flight Test-11 or IFT-11 lifted off from Starbase, Texas and splashed down in the Indian Ocean about an hour later. This was the last flight of this version of Starship, however, so the next launch will introduce new uncertainties as the United States strives to get American astronauts back on the Moon. Acting NASA Administrator Sean Duffy is determined to get American astronauts back on the Moon before China puts taikonauts there, which it plans to do by 2030. SpaceX webcast commentators tonight said the “research, development and technology” missions to Mars will begin in 2030, adding that comparable missions to the Moon will start in 2028.

title: JPL Lays Off Another 550 Workers
summary: The Jet Propulsion Laboratory is laying off another 550 workers beginning tomorrow.  JPL Director David Gallagher said the move is due to an ongoing reorganization that began in July, not […]
detailed_news: The Jet Propulsion Laboratory is laying off another 550 workers beginning tomorrow. JPL Director David Gallagher said the move is due to an ongoing reorganization that began in July, not because of the government shutdown. The number represents an 11 percent cutback and comes on top of two layoffs last year. JPL’s Full Time Equivalent (FTE) workforce has dropped by about 25 percent since December 2023. detailed_news: SpaceX is preparing to launch its Falcon 9 rocket from Cape Canaveral Space Force Station with two dozen of Amazon’s Project Kuiper broadband internet satellites onboard. title: One of SpaceX’s earliest employees is going to space—via Blue Origin
summary: "I've always been interested to experience Max Q from the inside."
detailed_news: Hans Koenigsmann is one of SpaceX's earliest, longest-tenured, and most-revered employees. He was brought on to develop avionics for the Falcon 1 rocket. He will fly with his friend Michaela "Michi" Benthaus as early as next month. Hans Koenigsmann will be the first person to fly on SpaceX's new New Shepard rocket. Koenigsman: "I just want to see the whole thing from above and get an idea of how big it really is in terms of curvature" "I want to be able to say that I saw that Earth is a sphere," he says.

title: DLR Delivers Callisto Landing Leg Prototype for Testing
summary:

Callisto is an international reusable rocket demonstrator jointly developed by DLR, CNES, and JAXA. The project’s primary goal is the development and maturation of […]
The post DLR Delivers Callisto Landing Leg Prototype for Testing appeared first on European Spaceflight.
detailed_news: Callisto is an international reusable rocket demonstrator jointly developed by DLR, CNES, and JAXA. The project’s primary goal is the development and maturation of key technologies for future reusable launch systems. The Callisto demonstrator will be equipped with four landing legs designed to absorb the impact of propulsive recovery and keep the rocket upright.

title: Special economic zones for restoring American space dominance
summary:
Will China beat America in returning astronauts to the moon? We hear this question time and again. It is a perennial concern, both from a prestige and national security standpoint. But it is the wrong question. What we really need to assess is whether or not China is on track to dominate America in space.  […]

title: Momentus and Solstar to offer communications, transportation and infrastructure in low-Earth orbit
summary:
BRISBANE, Australia – Momentus and Solstar Space announced a three-year agreement Oct. 13 to expand communications, transportation and infrastructure services for government and commercial missions in low-Earth orbit. The reciprocal-services agreement is designed to combine “the respective strengths, products and services of each company to deliver comprehensive low-Earth orbit space capabilities to address a broad […]

title: JAXA to launch tech demo satellites on Electron rockets
summary:
The Japanese space agency JAXA has selected Rocket Lab to launch a set of technology demonstration satellites on Electron rockets after continued delays with a Japanese launch vehicle.

title: Ramses: ESA’s mission to rendezvous with asteroid Apophis
summary: Friday the 13th of April 2029 will be our lucky day.
detailed_news: Apophis, a 375-metre-wide asteroid, will safely pass Earth at a distance of less than 32,000 kilometres. For a few hours, Apophis will be visible to the naked eye from Europe and Africa. Space agencies have sent a number of spacecraft to asteroids, but we have never had a mission at an asteroid as it sweeps past a planet.

title: Swarm reveals growing weak spot in Earth’s magnetic field
summary: Using 11 years of magnetic field measurements from the European Space Agency’s Swarm satellite constellation, scientists have discovered that the weak region in Earth’s magnetic field over the South Atlantic – known as the South Atlantic Anomaly – has expanded by an area nearly half the size of continental Europe since 2014.
detailed_news: Earth’s magnetic field is vital to life on our planet. It is largely generated by a global ocean of molten, swirling liquid iron that makes up the outer core around 3000 km beneath our feet. The weak field South Atlantic Anomaly was first identified southeast of South America back in the 19th century. Earth’s magnetic field strengthens over Siberia. Magnetic field over Siberia has strengthened while it has weakened over Canada. This shift is associated with the northern magnetic pole moving towards Siberia in recent years. The shift is important for navigation, which is affected by the dance between these two areas of strong magnetic field.

title: Live coverage: SpaceX to launch final Version 2 Starship-Super Heavy from Starbase
summary: The mission is also projected to be the final launch of the Starship program for the year. Liftoff is scheduled for 6:15 p.m. CDT (7:15 p.m. EDT / 2315 UTC).
detailed_news: SpaceX is scheduled to launch its Starship-Super Heavy rocket from its headquarters in Starbase, Texas, on Monday evening. The 11th flight test of the integrated Starship launch vehicle will be the final mission both for the Version 2 iteration of the rocket as well as the current configuration of Pad A. SpaceX will reuse 24 out of the 33 Raptor 2 engines on B15 during the Flight 11 mission. A commercial lunar lander built by Astrobotic will launch from the Kennedy Space Center on a SpaceX Falcon Heavy rocket in late 2023. Two South Korean Earth-watching satellites will ride Ariane 5 rockets into orbit in 2018 and 2019. Arianespace beat SpaceX in a competition to launch the spacecraft.
